dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Tranio, since for the great desire I had To see fair Padua, nursery of arts, I am arriv'd for fruitful Lombardy, The pleasant garden of great Italy, And by my father's love and leave am arm'd With his good will and thy good company, My trusty servant well approv'd in all, Here let us breathe, and haply institute A course of learning and ingenious studies. Pisa, renowned for grave citizens, Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii. Vincentio's son, brought up in Florence, It shall become to serve all hopes conceiv'd, To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds: And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study, Virtue and that part of philosophy Will I apply that treats of happiness By virtue specially to be achiev'd. Tell me thy mind; for I have Pisa left And am to Padua come as he that leaves A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep, And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: _Mi perdonato_, gentle master mine; I am in all affected as yourself; Glad that you thus continue your resolve To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy. Only, good master, while we do admire This virtue and this moral discipline, Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray; Or so devote to Aristotle's checks As Ovid be an outcast quite abjur'd. Balk logic with acquaintance that you have, And practise rhetoric in your common talk; Music and poesy use to quicken you; The mathematics and the metaphysics, Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you: No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en; In brief, sir, study what you most affect.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise. If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore, We could at once put us in readiness, And take a lodging fit to entertain Such friends as time in Padua shall beget. But stay awhile; what company is this?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, importune me no farther, For how I firmly am resolv'd you know; That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter Before I have a husband for the elder. If either of you both love Katherina, Because I know you well and love you well, Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: To cart her rather: she's too rough for me. There, there, Hortensio, will you any wife?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, is it your will To make a stale of me amongst these mates?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Mates, maid! How mean you that? No mates for you, Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I' faith, sir, you shall never need to fear; I wis it is not half way to her heart; But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool, And paint your face, and use you like a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: And me, too, good Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Husht, master! Here's some good pastime toward: That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: But in the other's silence do I see Maid's mild behaviour and sobriety. Peace, Tranio!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Well said, master; mum! and gaze your fill.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, that I may soon make good What I have said,-Bianca, get you in: And let it not displease thee, good Bianca, For I will love thee ne'er the less, my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: A pretty peat! it is best put finger in the eye, and she knew why.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Sister, content you in my discontent. Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to look, and practise by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Hark, Tranio! thou mayst hear Minerva speak.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange? Sorry am I that our good will effects Bianca's grief.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell, And make her bear the penance of her tongue?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolv'd. Go in, Bianca. And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments, and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio, Or, Signior Gremio, you, know any such, Prefer them hither; for to cunning men I will be very kind, and liberal To mine own children in good bringing up; And so, farewell. Katherina, you may stay; For I have more to commune with Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not? What! shall I be appointed hours, as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave? Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: You may go to the devil's dam: your gifts are so good here's none will hold you. Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly out; our cake's dough on both sides. Farewell: yet, for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: So will I, Signior Gremio: but a word, I pray. Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle, know now, upon advice, it toucheth us both,-that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress, and be happy rivals in Bianca's love,-to labour and effect one thing specially.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: What's that, I pray?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: A husband! a devil.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I say, a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I say, a devil. Thinkest thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Tush, Gremio! Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, and a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition: to be whipp'd at the high cross every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rotten apples. But come; since this bar in law makes us friends, it shall be so far forth friendly maintained, till by helping Baptista's eldest daughter to a husband, we set his youngest free for a husband, and then have to't afresh. Sweet Bianca! Happy man be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring. How say you, Signior Gremio?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I am agreed; and would I had given him the best horse in Padua to begin his wooing, that would thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: O Tranio! till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely; But see, while idly I stood looking on, I found the effect of love in idleness; And now in plainness do confess to thee, That art to me as secret and as dear As Anna to the Queen of Carthage was, Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio, If I achieve not this young modest girl. Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst: Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Master, it is no time to chide you now; Affection is not rated from the heart: If love have touch'd you, nought remains but so: _Redime te captum quam queas minimo._

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Gramercies, lad; go forward; this contents; The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Master, you look'd so longly on the maid. Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: O, yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face, Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand, When with his knees he kiss'd the Cretan strand.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Saw you no more? mark'd you not how her sister Began to scold and raise up such a storm That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move, And with her breath she did perfume the air; Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance. I pray, awake, sir: if you love the maid, Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands: Her elder sister is so curst and shrewd, That till the father rid his hands of her, Master, your love must live a maid at home; And therefore has he closely mew'd her up, Because she will not be annoy'd with suitors.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father's he! But art thou not advis'd he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, am I, sir, and now 'tis plotted.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I have it, Tranio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Tell me thine first.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: You will be schoolmaster, And undertake the teaching of the maid: That's your device.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: It is: may it be done?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Not possible; for who shall bear your part And be in Padua here Vincentio's son; Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends; Visit his countrymen, and banquet them?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: _Basta_, content thee, for I have it full. We have not yet been seen in any house, Nor can we be distinguish'd by our faces For man or master: then it follows thus: Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead, Keep house and port and servants, as I should; I will some other be; some Florentine, Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa. 'Tis hatch'd, and shall be so: Tranio, at once Uncase thee; take my colour'd hat and cloak. When Biondello comes, he waits on thee; But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: So had you need. In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is, And I am tied to be obedient; For so your father charg'd me at our parting, ‘Be serviceable to my son,' quoth he, Although I think 'twas in another sense: I am content to be Lucentio, Because so well I love Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves; And let me be a slave, to achieve that maid Whose sudden sight hath thrall'd my wounded eye. Here comes the rogue. Sirrah, where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Where have I been? Nay, how now! where are you? Master, has my fellow Tranio stol'n your clothes? Or you stol'n his? or both? Pray, what's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Sirrah, come hither: 'tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time. Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life, Puts my apparel and my count'nance on, And I for my escape have put on his; For in a quarrel since I came ashore I kill'd a man, and fear I was descried. Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes, While I make way from hence to save my life. You understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I, sir! Ne'er a whit.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth: Tranio is changed to Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: The better for him: would I were so too!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter. But, sirrah, not for my sake but your master's, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies: When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio; But in all places else your master, Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Tranio, let's go. One thing more rests, that thyself execute, To make one among these wooers: if thou ask me why, Sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.

dialogues.speaker: Sly
dialogues.line: Yes, by Saint Anne, I do. A good matter, surely: comes there any more of it?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: My lord, 'tis but begun.

dialogues.speaker: Sly
dialogues.line: 'Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady: would 'twere done!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua; but of all My best beloved and approved friend, Hortensio; and I trow this is his house. Here, sirrah Grumio, knock, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Is there any man has rebused your worship?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Knock you here, sir? Why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate; And rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first, And then I know after who comes by the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Will it not be? Faith, sirrah, and you'll not knock, I'll ring it; I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Help, masters, help! my master is mad.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Now, knock when I bid you, sirrah villain!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: How now! what's the matter? My old friend Grumio! and my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray? _Con tutto il cuore ben trovato_, may I say.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: _Alla nostra casa ben venuto; molto honorato signor mio Petruchio._ Rise, Grumio, rise: we will compound this quarrel.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin. If this be not a lawful cause for me to leave his service, look you, sir, he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir: well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so; being, perhaps, for aught I see, two-and-thirty, a pip out? Whom would to God I had well knock'd at first, then had not Grumio come by the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A senseless villain! Good Hortensio, I bade the rascal knock upon your gate, And could not get him for my heart to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Knock at the gate! O heavens! Spake you not these words plain: ‘Sirrah knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly'? And come you now with ‘knocking at the gate'?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge; Why, this's a heavy chance 'twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio. And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home, Where small experience grows. But in a few, Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me: Antonio, my father, is deceas'd, And I have thrust myself into this maze, Haply to wive and thrive as best I may; Crowns in my purse I have, and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favour'd wife? Thou'dst thank me but a little for my counsel; And yet I'll promise thee she shall be rich, And very rich: but th'art too much my friend, And I'll not wish thee to her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as we Few words suffice; and therefore, if thou know One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife, As wealth is burden of my wooing dance, Be she as foul as was Florentius' love, As old as Sibyl, and as curst and shrewd As Socrates' Xanthippe or a worse, She moves me not, or not removes, at least, Affection's edge in me, were she as rough As are the swelling Adriatic seas: I come to wive it wealthily in Padua; If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatly what his mind is: why, give him gold enough and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby; or an old trot with ne'er a tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two-and-fifty horses: why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Petruchio, since we are stepp'd thus far in, I will continue that I broach'd in jest. I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough, and young and beauteous; Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman: Her only fault,-and that is faults enough,- Is, that she is intolerable curst, And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure, That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Hortensio, peace! thou know'st not gold's effect: Tell me her father's name, and 'tis enough; For I will board her, though she chide as loud As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman; Her name is Katherina Minola, Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I know her father, though I know not her; And he knew my deceased father well. I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her; And therefore let me be thus bold with you, To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts. O' my word, and she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him. She may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so; why, that's nothing; and he begin once, he'll rail in his rope-tricks. I'll tell you what, sir, and she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face, and so disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat. You know him not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista's keep my treasure is: He hath the jewel of my life in hold, His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca, And her withholds from me and other more, Suitors to her and rivals in my love; Supposing it a thing impossible, For those defects I have before rehears'd, That ever Katherina will be woo'd: Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en, That none shall have access unto Bianca Till Katherine the curst have got a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Katherine the curst! A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguis'd in sober robes, To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca; That so I may, by this device at least Have leave and leisure to make love to her, And unsuspected court her by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together! Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Peace, Grumio! It is the rival of my love. Petruchio, stand by awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: A proper stripling, and an amorous!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: O! very well; I have perus'd the note. Hark you, sir; I'll have them very fairly bound: All books of love, see that at any hand, And see you read no other lectures to her. You understand me. Over and beside Signior Baptista's liberality, I'll mend it with a largess. Take your papers too, And let me have them very well perfum'd; For she is sweeter than perfume itself To whom they go to. What will you read to her?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you, As for my patron, stand you so assur'd, As firmly as yourself were still in place; Yea, and perhaps with more successful words Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: O! this learning, what a thing it is.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: O! this woodcock, what an ass it is.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Peace, sirrah!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio. Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola. I promis'd to enquire carefully About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca; And by good fortune I have lighted well On this young man; for learning and behaviour Fit for her turn, well read in poetry And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: 'Tis well; and I have met a gentleman Hath promis'd me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress: So shall I no whit be behind in duty To fair Bianca, so belov'd of me.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Belov'd of me, and that my deeds shall prove.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: And that his bags shall prove.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love: Listen to me, and if you speak me fair, I'll tell you news indifferent good for either. Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met, Upon agreement from us to his liking, Will undertake to woo curst Katherine; Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: So said, so done, is well. Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I know she is an irksome brawling scold; If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Born in Verona, old Antonio's son. My father dead, my fortune lives for me; And I do hope good days and long to see.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange! But if you have a stomach, to't a God's name; You shall have me assisting you in all. But will you woo this wild-cat?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Will I live?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Will he woo her? Ay, or I'll hang her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why came I hither but to that intent? Think you a little din can daunt mine ears? Have I not in my time heard lions roar? Have I not heard the sea, puff'd up with winds, Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat? Have I not heard great ordnance in the field, And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies? Have I not in a pitched battle heard Loud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang? And do you tell me of a woman's tongue, That gives not half so great a blow to hear As will a chestnut in a farmer's fire? Tush, tush! fear boys with bugs.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: For he fears none.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Hortensio, hark: This gentleman is happily arriv'd, My mind presumes, for his own good and yours.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I promis'd we would be contributors, And bear his charge of wooing, whatsoe'er.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: And so we will, provided that he win her.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, God save you! If I may be bold, Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: He that has the two fair daughters; is't he you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Even he, Biondello!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Hark you, sir, you mean not her to-

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Perhaps him and her, sir; what have you to do?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let's away.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Well begun, Tranio.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sir, a word ere you go. Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And if I be, sir, is it any offence?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: No; if without more words you will get you hence.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: But so is not she.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: For what reason, I beseech you?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: For this reason, if you'll know, That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Softly, my masters! If you be gentlemen, Do me this right; hear me with patience. Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown; And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have, and me for one. Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have; And so she shall: Lucentio shall make one, Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: What, this gentleman will out-talk us all.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Sir, give him head; I know he'll prove a jade.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you, Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongue As is the other for beauteous modesty.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules, And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth: The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for, Her father keeps from all access of suitors, And will not promise her to any man Until the elder sister first be wed; The younger then is free, and not before.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: If it be so, sir, that you are the man Must stead us all, and me amongst the rest; And if you break the ice, and do this feat, Achieve the elder, set the younger free For our access, whose hap shall be to have her Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive; And since you do profess to be a suitor, You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman, To whom we all rest generally beholding.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Sir, I shall not be slack; in sign whereof, Please ye we may contrive this afternoon, And quaff carouses to our mistress' health; And do as adversaries do in law, Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends. GRUMIO, BIONDELLO. O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: The motion's good indeed, and be it so:- Petruchio, I shall be your _ben venuto_.

scenes.location: Padua. A room in Baptista's house.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me; That I disdain; but for these other gawds, Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself, Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat; Or what you will command me will I do, So well I know my duty to my elders.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Of all thy suitors here I charge thee tell Whom thou lov'st best: see thou dissemble not.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive I never yet beheld that special face Which I could fancy more than any other.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: If you affect him, sister, here I swear I'll plead for you myself but you shall have him.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: O! then, belike, you fancy riches more: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Is it for him you do envy me so? Nay, then you jest; and now I well perceive You have but jested with me all this while: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, how now, dame! Whence grows this insolence? Bianca, stand aside. Poor girl! she weeps. Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her. For shame, thou hilding of a devilish spirit, Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee? When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Her silence flouts me, and I'll be reveng'd.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: What! in my sight? Bianca, get thee in.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: What! will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see She is your treasure, she must have a husband; I must dance bare-foot on her wedding-day, And, for your love to her, lead apes in hell. Talk not to me: I will go sit and weep Till I can find occasion of revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Was ever gentleman thus griev'd as I? But who comes here? Enter Gremio, with Lucentio in the habit of a mean man; Petruchio, with Hortensio as a musician; and Tranio, with Biondello bearing a lute and books.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio. God save you, gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughter Call'd Katherina, fair and virtuous?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I have a daughter, sir, call'd Katherina.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave. I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That, hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behaviour, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Of that report which I so oft have heard. And, for an entrance to my entertainment, I do present you with a man of mine, Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof I know she is not ignorant. Accept of him, or else you do me wrong: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Y'are welcome, sir, and he for your good sake; But for my daughter Katherine, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I see you do not mean to part with her; Or else you like not of my company.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Mistake me not; I speak but as I find. Whence are you, sir? What may I call your name?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Petruchio is my name, Antonio's son; A man well known throughout all Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray, Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too. Backare! you are marvellous forward.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your wooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar, that has been long studying at Rheims; as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other in music and mathematics. His name is Cambio; pray accept his service.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio; welcome, good Cambio.  But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger. May I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That, being a stranger in this city here, Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous. Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister. This liberty is all that I request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo, And free access and favour as the rest: And, toward the education of your daughters, I here bestow a simple instrument, And this small packet of Greek and Latin books: If you accept them, then their worth is great.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Lucentio is your name, of whence, I pray?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: A mighty man of Pisa: by report I know him well: you are very welcome, sir.  Take you the lute,  and you the set of books; You shall go see your pupils presently. Holla, within! Sirrah, lead these gentlemen To my daughters, and tell them both These are their tutors: bid them use them well. We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner. You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo. You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have bettered rather than decreas'd: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: After my death, the one half of my lands, And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever. Let specialities be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd, That is, her love; for that is all in all.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, that is nothing; for I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury: Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all; So I to her, and so she yields to me; For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed! But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds, That shake not though they blow perpetually.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: How now, my friend! Why dost thou look so pale?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I think she'll sooner prove a soldier: Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Why, no; for she hath broke the lute to me. I did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering; When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, ‘Frets, call you these?' quoth she ‘I'll fume with them'; And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way; And there I stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute; While she did call me rascal fiddler, And twangling Jack, with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench! I love her ten times more than e'er I did: O! how I long to have some chat with her!

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Well, go with me, and be not so discomfited; Proceed in practice with my younger daughter; She's apt to learn, and thankful for good turns. Signior Petruchio, will you go with us, Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I pray you do. I will attend her here, And woo her with some spirit when she comes. Say that she rail; why, then I'll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale: Say that she frown; I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly wash'd with dew: Say she be mute, and will not speak a word; Then I'll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day When I shall ask the banns, and when be married. But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak. Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing: They call me Katherine that do talk of me.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: You lie, in faith, for you are call'd plain Kate, And bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst; But, Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom, Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate, For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation; Hearing thy mildness prais'd in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,- Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,- Myself am mov'd to woo thee for my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Mov'd! in good time: let him that mov'd you hither Remove you hence. I knew you at the first, You were a moveable.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, what's a moveable?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: A joint-stool.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: No such jade as bear you, if me you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee; For, knowing thee to be but young and light,-

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Too light for such a swain as you to catch; And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Should be! should buz!

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: O, slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: My remedy is then to pluck it out.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting? In his tail.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: In his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Whose tongue?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Yours, if you talk of tales; and so farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: What! with my tongue in your tail? Nay, come again, Good Kate; I am a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: That I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I swear I'll cuff you if you strike again.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: So may you lose your arms: If you strike me, you are no gentleman; And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A herald, Kate? O! put me in thy books.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: What is your crest? a coxcomb?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: It is my fashion when I see a crab.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, here's no crab, and therefore look not sour.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: There is, there is.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Then show it me.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Had I a glass I would.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: What, you mean my face?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Well aim'd of such a young one.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Yet you are wither'd.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: 'Tis with cares.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I care not.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth, you 'scape not so.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I chafe you, if I tarry; let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: No, not a whit; I find you passing gentle. 'Twas told me you were rough, and coy, and sullen, And now I find report a very liar; For thou art pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous, But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers. Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk; But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers; With gentle conference, soft and affable. Why does the world report that Kate doth limp? O sland'rous world! Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender, and as brown in hue As hazel-nuts, and sweeter than the kernels. O! let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait? O! be thou Dian, and let her be Kate, And then let Kate be chaste, and Dian sportful!

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: A witty mother! witless else her son.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Am I not wise?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Yes; keep you warm.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katherine, in thy bed; And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife your dowry 'greed on; And will you, nill you, I will marry you. Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn; For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,- Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,- Thou must be married to no man but me; For I am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates. Here comes your father. Never make denial; I must and will have Katherine to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: How but well, sir? how but well? It were impossible I should speed amiss.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, how now, daughter Katherine, in your dumps?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Call you me daughter? Now I promise you You have show'd a tender fatherly regard To wish me wed to one half lunatic, A mad-cap ruffian and a swearing Jack, That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world That talk'd of her have talk'd amiss of her: If she be curst, it is for policy, For she's not froward, but modest as the dove; She is not hot, but temperate as the morn; For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity; And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see thee hang'd first.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Is this your speeding? Nay, then good-night our part!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Be patient, gentlemen. I choose her for myself; If she and I be pleas'd, what's that to you? 'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company. I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me: O! the kindest Kate She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love. O! you are novices: 'tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. Give me thy hand, Kate; I will unto Venice, To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day. Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests; I will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I know not what to say; but give me your hands. God send you joy, Petruchio! 'Tis a match. GREMIO, TRANIO. Amen, say we; we will be witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu. I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace; We will have rings and things, and fine array; And kiss me, Kate; we will be married o' Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part, And venture madly on a desperate mart.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you; 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch. But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter: Now is the day we long have looked for; I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And I am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness or your thoughts can guess.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Greybeard, thy love doth freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: But thine doth fry. Skipper, stand back; 'tis age that nourisheth.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Content you, gentlemen; I'll compound this strife: 'Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love. Say, Signior Gremio, what can you assure her?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold: Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry; In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns; In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions boss'd with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework; Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping: then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion. Myself am struck in years, I must confess; And if I die tomorrow this is hers, If whilst I live she will be only mine.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: That ‘only' came well in. Sir, list to me: I am my father's heir and only son; If I may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good Within rich Pisa's walls as anyone Old Signior Gremio has in Padua; Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure. What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Two thousand ducats by the year of land! My land amounts not to so much in all: That she shall have, besides an argosy That now is lying in Marseilles' road. What, have I chok'd you with an argosy?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses, And twelve tight galleys; these I will assure her, And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Nay, I have offer'd all; I have no more; And she can have no more than all I have; If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise; Gremio is out-vied.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I must confess your offer is the best; And let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me; If you should die before him, where's her dower?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: That's but a cavil; he is old, I young.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: And may not young men die as well as old?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolv'd. On Sunday next, you know, My daughter Katherine is to be married; Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca Be bride to you, if you make this assurance; If not, to Signior Gremio. And so I take my leave, and thank you both.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Adieu, good neighbour. Now, I fear thee not: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all, and in his waning age Set foot under thy table. Tut! a toy! An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide! Yet I have fac'd it with a card of ten. 'Tis in my head to do my master good: I see no reason but suppos'd Lucentio Must get a father, call'd suppos'd Vincentio; And that's a wonder: fathers commonly Do get their children; but in this case of wooing A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

scenes.location: Padua. A room in Baptista's house.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir. Have you so soon forgot the entertainment Her sister Katherine welcome'd you withal?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: But, wrangling pedant, this is The patroness of heavenly harmony: Then give me leave to have prerogative; And when in music we have spent an hour, Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordain'd! Was it not to refresh the mind of man After his studies or his usual pain? Then give me leave to read philosophy, And while I pause serve in your harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong, To strive for that which resteth in my choice. I am no breeching scholar in the schools, I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times, But learn my lessons as I please myself. And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down; Take you your instrument, play you the whiles; His lecture will be done ere you have tun'd.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: That will be never: tune your instrument.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Where left we last?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Here, madam:- _Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus; Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis._

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Construe them.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: _Hic ibat_, as I told you before, _Simois_, I am Lucentio, _hic est_, son unto Vincentio of Pisa, _Sigeia tellus_, disguised thus to get your love, _Hic steterat_, and that Lucentio that comes a-wooing, _Priami_, is my man Tranio, _regia_, bearing my port, _celsa senis_, that we might beguile the old pantaloon. HORTENSIO.  Madam, my instrument's in tune.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Let's hear.- O fie! the treble jars.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Now let me see if I can construe it: _Hic ibat Simois_, I know you not; _hic est Sigeia tellus_, I trust you not; _Hic steterat Priami_, take heed he hear us not; _regia_, presume not; _celsa senis_, despair not.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Madam, 'tis now in tune.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: All but the base.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars.  How fiery and forward our pedant is! Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love: Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Mistrust it not; for sure, Æacides Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt; But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you. Good master, take it not unkindly, pray, That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: You may go walk and give me leave a while; My lessons make no music in three parts.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Are you so formal, sir? Well, I must wait,  And watch withal; for, but I be deceiv'd, Our fine musician groweth amorous.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Madam, before you touch the instrument, To learn the order of my fingering, I must begin with rudiments of art; To teach you gamut in a briefer sort, More pleasant, pithy, and effectual, Than hath been taught by any of my trade: And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: _Gamut_ I am, the ground of all accord, _A re_, to plead Hortensio's passion; _B mi_, Bianca, take him for thy lord, _C fa ut_, that loves with all affection: _D sol re_, one clef, two notes have I _E la mi_, show pity or I die. Call you this gamut? Tut, I like it not: Old fashions please me best; I am not so nice, To change true rules for odd inventions.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books, And help to dress your sister's chamber up: You know tomorrow is the wedding-day.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Farewell, sweet masters, both: I must be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: But I have cause to pry into this pedant: Methinks he looks as though he were in love. Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble To cast thy wand'ring eyes on every stale, Seize thee that list: if once I find thee ranging, Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: No shame but mine; I must, forsooth, be forc'd To give my hand, oppos'd against my heart, Unto a mad-brain rudesby, full of spleen; Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure. I told you, I, he was a frantic fool, Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behaviour; And to be noted for a merry man, He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage, Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banns; Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd. Now must the world point at poor Katherine, And say ‘Lo! there is mad Petruchio's wife, If it would please him come and marry her.'

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Patience, good Katherine, and Baptista too. Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Would Katherine had never seen him though!

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Go, girl, I cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint; Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour. Master, master! News! old news, and such news as you never heard of!

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Is it new and old too? How may that be?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio's coming?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Is he come?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Why, no, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: He is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: When will he be here?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: But say, what to thine old news?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Why, Petruchio is coming, in a new hat and an old jerkin; a pair of old breeches thrice turned; a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another laced; an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town armoury, with a broken hilt, and chapeless; with two broken points: his horse hipped with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine; troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of windgalls, sped with spavins, rayed with the yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten; near-legged before, and with a half-checked bit, and a head-stall of sheep's leather, which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst, and now repaired with knots; one girth six times pieced, and a woman's crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with pack-thread.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Who comes with him?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: O, sir! his lackey, for all the world caparisoned like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and blue list; an old hat, and the humour of forty fancies prick'd in't for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: 'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion; Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Why, sir, he comes not.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Didst thou not say he comes?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Who? that Petruchio came?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Ay, that Petruchio came.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: No, sir; I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, that's all one.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one, And yet not many.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come, where be these gallants? Who is at home?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: You are welcome, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: And yet I come not well.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: And yet you halt not.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Not so well apparell'd as I wish you were.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Were it better, I should rush in thus. But where is Kate? Where is my lovely bride? How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown; And wherefore gaze this goodly company, As if they saw some wondrous monument, Some comet or unusual prodigy?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day: First were we sad, fearing you would not come; Now sadder, that you come so unprovided. Fie! doff this habit, shame to your estate, An eye-sore to our solemn festival.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And tell us what occasion of import Hath all so long detain'd you from your wife, And sent you hither so unlike yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear; Sufficeth I am come to keep my word, Though in some part enforced to digress; Which at more leisure I will so excuse As you shall well be satisfied withal. But where is Kate? I stay too long from her; The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: See not your bride in these unreverent robes; Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words; To me she's married, not unto my clothes. Could I repair what she will wear in me As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself. But what a fool am I to chat with you When I should bid good morrow to my bride, And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: He hath some meaning in his mad attire. We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I'll after him and see the event of this.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: But, sir, to love concerneth us to add Her father's liking; which to bring to pass, As I before imparted to your worship, I am to get a man,-whate'er he be It skills not much; we'll fit him to our turn,- And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa, And make assurance here in Padua, Of greater sums than I have promised. So shall you quietly enjoy your hope, And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Were it not that my fellow schoolmaster Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly, 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage; Which once perform'd, let all the world say no, I'll keep mine own despite of all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: That by degrees we mean to look into, And watch our vantage in this business. We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Licio; All for my master's sake, Lucentio. Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: As willingly as e'er I came from school.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: A bridegroom, say you? 'Tis a groom indeed, A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Curster than she? Why, 'tis impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Why, he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Tut! she's a lamb, a dove, a fool, to him. I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest Should ask if Katherine should be his wife, 'Ay, by gogs-wouns' quoth he, and swore so loud That, all amaz'd, the priest let fall the book; And as he stoop'd again to take it up, The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff That down fell priest and book, and book and priest: ‘Now take them up,' quoth he ‘if any list.'

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: What said the wench, when he rose again?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Trembled and shook, for why, he stamp'd and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him. But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine: ‘A health!' quoth he, as if He had been abroad, carousing to his mates After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel, And threw the sops all in the sexton's face, Having no other reason But that his beard grew thin and hungerly And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking. This done, he took the bride about the neck, And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo. And I, seeing this, came thence for very shame; And after me, I know, the rout is coming. Such a mad marriage never was before. Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play. Train.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains: I know you think to dine with me today, And have prepar'd great store of wedding cheer But so it is, my haste doth call me hence, And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Is't possible you will away tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I must away today before night come. Make it no wonder: if you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay. And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet, and virtuous wife. Dine with my father, drink a health to me. For I must hence; and farewell to you all.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: It may not be.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Let me entreat you.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: It cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Let me entreat you.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I am content.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Are you content to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I am content you shall entreat me stay; But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Now, if you love me, stay.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Grumio, my horse!

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Nay, then, Do what thou canst, I will not go today; No, nor tomorrow, not till I please myself. The door is open, sir; there lies your way; You may be jogging whiles your boots are green; For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself. 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom That take it on you at the first so roundly.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: O Kate! content thee: prithee be not angry.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I will be angry: what hast thou to do? Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner: I see a woman may be made a fool, If she had not a spirit to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command. Obey the bride, you that attend on her; Go to the feast, revel and domineer, Carouse full measure to her maidenhead, Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me. Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret; I will be master of what is mine own. She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house, My household stuff, my field, my barn, My horse, my ox, my ass, my anything; And here she stands, touch her whoever dare; I'll bring mine action on the proudest he That stops my way in Padua. Grumio, Draw forth thy weapon; we are beset with thieves; Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man. Fear not, sweet wench; they shall not touch thee, Kate; I'll buckler thee against a million.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Of all mad matches, never was the like.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Neighbours and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast. Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place; And let Bianca take her sister's room.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.

scenes.location: A hall in Petruchio's country house.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? Was ever man so ray'd? Was ever man so weary? I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them. Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me. But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself; for, considering the weather, a taller man than I will take cold. Holla, ho! Curtis!

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Who is that calls so coldly?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck. A fire, good Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: O, ay! Curtis, ay; and therefore fire, fire; cast on no water.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: She was, good Curtis, before this frost; but thou knowest winter tames man, woman, and beast; for it hath tamed my old master, and my new mistress, and myself, fellow Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Am I but three inches? Why, thy horn is a foot; and so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand,-she being now at hand,- thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; and therefore fire. Do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Why, ‘Jack boy! ho, boy!' and as much news as wilt thou.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Come, you are so full of cony-catching.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Why, therefore, fire; for I have caught extreme cold. Where's the cook? Is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the servingmen in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on? Be the Jacks fair within, the Jills fair without, and carpets laid, and everything in order?

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: First, know my horse is tired; my master and mistress fallen out.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: How?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs a tale.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Lend thine ear.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: There.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: This 'tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale; and this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech listening. Now I begin: _Imprimis_, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,-

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Both of one horse?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: What's that to thee?

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Why, a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell, and she under her horse; thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place, how she was bemoiled; how he left her with the horse upon her; how he beat me because her horse stumbled; how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off me: how he swore; how she prayed, that never prayed before; how I cried; how the horses ran away; how her bridle was burst; how I lost my crupper; with many things of worthy memory, which now shall die in oblivion, and thou return unexperienced to thy grave.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home. But what talk I of this? Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest; let their heads be sleekly combed, their blue coats brush'd and their garters of an indifferent knit; let them curtsy with their left legs, and not presume to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: They are.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Call them forth.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Do you hear? ho! You must meet my master to countenance my mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Why, she hath a face of her own.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: Who knows not that?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: I call them forth to credit her.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Welcome home, Grumio!

dialogues.speaker: Philip
dialogues.line: How now, Grumio!

dialogues.speaker: Joseph
dialogues.line: What, Grumio!

dialogues.speaker: Nicholas
dialogues.line: Fellow Grumio!

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: How now, old lad!

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Welcome, you; how now, you; what, you; fellow, you; and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: All things is ready. How near is our master?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore be not,- Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Where be these knaves? What! no man at door To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse? Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?-

dialogues.speaker: All Servants
dialogues.line: Here, here, sir; here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms! What, no attendance? no regard? no duty? Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge! Did I not bid thee meet me in the park, And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made, And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel; There was no link to colour Peter's hat, And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing; There was none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory; The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly; Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Go, rascals, go and fetch my supper in. Where is the life that late I led? Where are those-?  Sit down, Kate, and welcome. Food, food, food, food! Why, when, I say?-Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.- Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains! when? It was the friar of orders grey, As he forth walked on his way: Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other. Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho! Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither: One, Kate, that you must kiss and be acquainted with. Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water? Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.- You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A whoreson, beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave! Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach. Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I?- What's this? Mutton?

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Who brought it?

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: I.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: 'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat. What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook? How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser, And serve it thus to me that love it not?
