There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all. You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves! What! do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet; The meat was well, if you were so contented.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away, And I expressly am forbid to touch it; For it engenders choler, planteth anger; And better 'twere that both of us did fast, Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric, Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh. Be patient; tomorrow 't shall be mended. And for this night we'll fast for company: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Peter, didst ever see the like?

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: He kills her in her own humour.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Curtis
dialogues.line: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her; And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul, Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak, And sits as one new risen from a dream. Away, away! for he is coming hither.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And 'tis my hope to end successfully. My falcon now is sharp and passing empty. And till she stoop she must not be full-gorg'd, For then she never looks upon her lure. Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come, and know her keeper's call, That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat, and will not be obedient. She eat no meat today, nor none shall eat; Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not; As with the meat, some undeserved fault I'll find about the making of the bed; And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets; Ay, and amid this hurly I intend That all is done in reverend care of her; And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl, And with the clamour keep her still awake. This is a way to kill a wife with kindness; And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour. He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak; 'tis charity to show.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Is 't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio? I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said, Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: What, master, read you? First resolve me that.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I read that I profess, _The Art to Love_.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Quick proceeders, marry! Now tell me, I pray, You that durst swear that your Mistress Bianca Lov'd none in the world so well as Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind! I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Mistake no more; I am not Licio. Nor a musician as I seem to be; But one that scorn to live in this disguise For such a one as leaves a gentleman And makes a god of such a cullion: Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard Of your entire affection to Bianca; And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness, I will with you, if you be so contented, Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: See, how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio, Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow Never to woo her more, but do forswear her, As one unworthy all the former favours That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And here I take the like unfeigned oath, Never to marry with her though she would entreat; Fie on her! See how beastly she doth court him!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn! For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow Ere three days pass, which hath as long lov'd me As I have lov'd this proud disdainful haggard. And so farewell, Signior Lucentio. Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love; and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case! Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Tranio, you jest; but have you both forsworn me?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Mistress, we have.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Then we are rid of Licio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now, That shall be woo'd and wedded in a day.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: God give him joy!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Ay, and he'll tame her.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: He says so, Tranio.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: The taming-school! What, is there such a place?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Ay, mistress; and Petruchio is the master, That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long, To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: O master, master! I have watch'd so long That I am dog-weary; but at last I spied An ancient angel coming down the hill Will serve the turn.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: What is he, Biondello?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Master, a mercatante or a pedant, I know not what; but formal in apparel, In gait and countenance surely like a father.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: And what of him, Tranio?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: If he be credulous and trust my tale, I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio, And give assurance to Baptista Minola, As if he were the right Vincentio. Take in your love, and then let me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: God save you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: And you, sir! you are welcome. Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two; But then up farther, and as far as Rome; And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: What countryman, I pray?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Of Mantua.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Of Mantua, sir?  Marry, God forbid, And come to Padua, careless of your life!

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: My life, sir! How, I pray? for that goes hard.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: 'Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua. Know you not the cause? Your ships are stay'd at Venice; and the Duke,- For private quarrel 'twixt your Duke and him,- Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly. 'Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Alas, sir! it is worse for me than so; For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence, and must here deliver them.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Well, sir, to do you courtesy, This will I do, and this I will advise you: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Among them know you one Vincentio?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: I know him not, but I have heard of him, A merchant of incomparable wealth.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say, In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: To save your life in this extremity, This favour will I do you for his sake; And think it not the worst of all your fortunes That you are like to Sir Vincentio. His name and credit shall you undertake, And in my house you shall be friendly lodg'd; Look that you take upon you as you should! You understand me, sir; so shall you stay Till you have done your business in the city. If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: O, sir, I do; and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Then go with me to make the matter good. This, by the way, I let you understand: My father is here look'd for every day To pass assurance of a dower in marriage 'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you. Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears. What, did he marry me to famish me? Beggars that come unto my father's door Upon entreaty have a present alms; If not, elsewhere they meet with charity; But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starv'd for meat, giddy for lack of sleep; With oaths kept waking, and with brawling fed. And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love; As who should say, if I should sleep or eat 'Twere deadly sickness, or else present death. I prithee go and get me some repast; I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: What say you to a neat's foot?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: 'Tis passing good; I prithee let me have it.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I fear it is too choleric a meat. How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I like it well; good Grumio, fetch it me.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric. What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Why then the beef, and let the mustard rest.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Nay, then I will not: you shall have the mustard, Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Why then the mustard without the beef.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, That feed'st me with the very name of meat. Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you That triumph thus upon my misery! Go, get thee gone, I say. Enter Petruchio with a dish of meat; and Hortensio.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Mistress, what cheer?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Faith, as cold as can be.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me. Here, love; thou seest how diligent I am, To dress thy meat myself, and bring it thee: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks. What! not a word? Nay, then thou lov'st it not, And all my pains is sorted to no proof. Here, take away this dish.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I pray you, let it stand.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: The poorest service is repaid with thanks; And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame. Come, Mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me. Much good do it unto thy gentle heart! Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love, Will we return unto thy father's house And revel it as bravely as the best, With silken coats and caps, and golden rings, With ruffs and cuffs and farthingales and things; With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery, With amber bracelets, beads, and all this knavery. What! hast thou din'd? The tailor stays thy leisure, To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure. Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments; Lay forth the gown.- What news with you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Haberdasher
dialogues.line: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, this was moulded on a porringer; A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap: Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I'll have no bigger; this doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: That will not be in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak; And speak I will. I am no child, no babe. Your betters have endur'd me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears. My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, Or else my heart, concealing it, will break; And rather than it shall, I will be free Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap, A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie; I love thee well in that thou lik'st it not.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Love me or love me not, I like the cap; And it I will have, or I will have none.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Thy gown? Why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't. O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here? What's this? A sleeve? 'Tis like a demi-cannon. What, up and down, carv'd like an apple tart? Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber's shop. Why, what i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd, I did not bid you mar it to the time. Go, hop me over every kennel home, For you shall hop without my custom, sir. I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I never saw a better fashion'd gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable; Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, Thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail! Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou! Brav'd in mine own house with a skein of thread! Away! thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant, Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou liv'st! I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: Your worship is deceiv'd: the gown is made Just as my master had direction. Grumio gave order how it should be done.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: But how did you desire it should be made?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: But did you not request to have it cut?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Thou hast faced many things.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Face not me. Thou hast braved many men; brave not me: I will neither be fac'd nor brav'd. I say unto thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown; but I did not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Read it.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: The note lies in 's throat, if he say I said so.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: 'Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown.'

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in the skirts of it and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread; I said, a gown.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: ‘With a small compassed cape.'

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I confess the cape.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: ‘With a trunk sleeve.'

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I confess two sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: ‘The sleeves curiously cut.'

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Ay, there's the villainy.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill. I commanded the sleeves should be cut out, and sew'd up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

dialogues.speaker: Tailor
dialogues.line: This is true that I say; and I had thee in place where thou shouldst know it.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: I am for thee straight; take thou the bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: God-a-mercy, Grumio! Then he shall have no odds.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: You are i' the right, sir; 'tis for my mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: Villain, not for thy life! Take up my mistress' gown for thy master's use!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

dialogues.speaker: Grumio
dialogues.line: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for. Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use! O fie, fie, fie!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.  Go take it hence; be gone, and say no more.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow; Take no unkindness of his hasty words. Away, I say! commend me to thy master.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's Even in these honest mean habiliments. Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich; And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, So honour peereth in the meanest habit. What, is the jay more precious than the lark Because his feathers are more beautiful? Or is the adder better than the eel Because his painted skin contents the eye? O no, good Kate; neither art thou the worse For this poor furniture and mean array. If thou account'st it shame, lay it on me; And therefore frolic; we will hence forthwith, To feast and sport us at thy father's house. Go call my men, and let us straight to him; And bring our horses unto Long-lane end; There will we mount, and thither walk on foot. Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock, And well we may come there by dinner-time.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two, And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: It shall be seven ere I go to horse. Look what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it. Sirs, let 't alone: I will not go today; and ere I do, It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Why, so this gallant will command the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Sir, this is the house; please it you that I call?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Ay, what else? and, but I be deceived, Signior Baptista may remember me, Near twenty years ago in Genoa, Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case, With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: I warrant you. But, sir, here comes your boy; 'Twere good he were school'd.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello, Now do your duty throughly, I advise you. Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Tut! fear not me.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Th'art a tall fellow; hold thee that to drink. Here comes Baptista. Set your countenance, sir. Signior Baptista, you are happily met.  Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of; I pray you stand good father to me now; Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Soft, son! Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio Made me acquainted with a weighty cause Of love between your daughter and himself: And,-for the good report I hear of you, And for the love he beareth to your daughter, And she to him,-to stay him not too long, I am content, in a good father's care, To have him match'd; and, if you please to like No worse than I, upon some agreement Me shall you find ready and willing With one consent to have her so bestow'd; For curious I cannot be with you, Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say. Your plainness and your shortness please me well. Right true it is your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter, and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections; And therefore, if you say no more than this, That like a father you will deal with him, And pass my daughter a sufficient dower, The match is made, and all is done: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best We be affied, and such assurance ta'en As shall with either part's agreement stand?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants; Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still, And happily we might be interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Then at my lodging, and it like you: There doth my father lie; and there this night We'll pass the business privately and well. Send for your daughter by your servant here; My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently. The worst is this, that at so slender warning You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: It likes me well. Cambio, hie you home, And bid Bianca make her ready straight; And, if you will, tell what hath happened: Lucentio's father is arriv'd in Padua, And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone. Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way? Welcome! One mess is like to be your cheer; Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: I follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Cambio!

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: What say'st thou, Biondello?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Biondello, what of that?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I pray thee moralize them.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: And what of him?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: And then?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: The old priest at Saint Luke's church is at your command at all hours.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: And what of all this?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance. Take your assurance of her, _cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum_; to the church! take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses. If this be not that you look for, I have more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Hear'st thou, Biondello?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir; and so adieu, sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I may, and will, if she be so contented. She will be pleas'd; then wherefore should I doubt? Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her; It shall go hard if Cambio go without her:

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's. Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: The moon! The sun; it is not moonlight now.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Now by my mother's son, and that's myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or ere I journey to your father's house. Go on and fetch our horses back again. Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far, And be it moon, or sun, or what you please; And if you please to call it a rush-candle, Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I say it is the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: I know it is the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, then you lie; it is the blessed sun.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun; But sun it is not when you say it is not, And the moon changes even as your mind. What you will have it nam'd, even that it is, And so it shall be so for Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run, And not unluckily against the bias. But, soft! Company is coming here.  Good morrow, gentle mistress; where away? Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too, Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman? Such war of white and red within her cheeks! What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty As those two eyes become that heavenly face? Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee. Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: A will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode? Happy the parents of so fair a child; Happier the man whom favourable stars Allot thee for his lovely bedfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd, And not a maiden, as thou sayst he is.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes, That have been so bedazzled with the sun That everything I look on seemeth green: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father; Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Do, good old grandsire, and withal make known Which way thou travellest: if along with us, We shall be joyful of thy company.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amaz'd me, My name is called Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa; And bound I am to Padua, there to visit A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: What is his name?

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Lucentio, gentle sir.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Happily met; the happier for thy son. And now by law, as well as reverend age, I may entitle thee my loving father: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not, Nor be not griev'd: she is of good esteem, Her dowry wealthy, and of worthy birth; Beside, so qualified as may beseem The spouse of any noble gentleman. Let me embrace with old Vincentio; And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: But is this true? or is it else your pleasure, Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest Upon the company you overtake?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof; For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart. Have to my widow! and if she be froward, Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I fly, Biondello; but they may chance to need thee at home, therefore leave us.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and then come back to my master's as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Sir, here's the door; this is Lucentio's house: My father's bears more toward the market-place; Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: You shall not choose but drink before you go. I think I shall command your welcome here, And by all likelihood some cheer is toward.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall need none so long as I live.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua. Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you tell Signior Lucentio that his father is come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua, and here looking out at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Art thou his father?

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, how now, gentleman! why, this is flat knavery to take upon you another man's name.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a means to cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I have seen them in the church together: God send 'em good shipping! But who is here? Mine old master, Vincentio! Now we are undone and brought to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Come hither, crack-hemp.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I hope I may choose, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Forgot you! No, sir: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: What, you notorious villain! didst thou never see thy master's father, Vincentio?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: What, my old worshipful old master? Yes, marry, sir; see where he looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Is't so, indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of this controversy. Re-enter Pedant, below; Baptista, Tranio and Servants.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet, a velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a copatain hat! O, I am undone! I am undone! While I play the good husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: How now! what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: What, is the man lunatic?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: You mistake, sir; you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: His name! As if I knew not his name! I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Away, away, mad ass! His name is Lucentio; and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold on him, I charge you, in the Duke's name. O, my son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son, Lucentio?

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Call forth an officer. Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Carry me to the gaol!

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Stay, officer; he shall not go to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Talk not, Signior Gremio; I say he shall go to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business; I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.

dialogues.speaker: Pedant
dialogues.line: Swear if thou darest.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Nay, I dare not swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Thus strangers may be haled and abus'd: O monstrous villain!

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: O! we are spoiled; and yonder he is: deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Pardon, sweet father.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Lives my sweetest son?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Pardon, dear father.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: How hast thou offended? Where is Lucentio?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Here's Lucentio, Right son to the right Vincentio; That have by marriage made thy daughter mine, While counterfeit supposes blear'd thine eyne.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Here 's packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Where is that damned villain, Tranio, That fac'd and brav'd me in this matter so?

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Cambio is chang'd into Lucentio.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town; And happily I have arriv'd at the last Unto the wished haven of my bliss. What Tranio did, myself enforc'd him to; Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: I'll slit the villain's nose that would have sent me to the gaol.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: But do you hear, sir? Have you married my daughter without asking my good will?

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I will in, to be revenged for this villainy.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: And I to sound the depth of this knavery.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: My cake is dough, but I'll in among the rest; Out of hope of all but my share of the feast. Petruchio and Katherina advance.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Husband, let's follow to see the end of this ado.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: What! in the midst of the street?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: What! art thou ashamed of me?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: No, sir; God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, then, let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate: Better once than never, for never too late.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree: And time it is when raging war is done, To smile at 'scapes and perils overblown. My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with self-same kindness welcome thine. Brother Petruchio, sister Katherina, And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow, Feast with the best, and welcome to my house: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down; For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: For both our sakes I would that word were true.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Then never trust me if I be afeard.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean Hortensio is afeard of you.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Roundly replied.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Mistress, how mean you that?

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Thus I conceive by him.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: My widow says thus she conceives her tale.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round': I pray you tell me what you meant by that.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew, Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe; And now you know my meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: A very mean meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Right, I mean you.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: And I am mean, indeed, respecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: To her, Kate!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: To her, widow!

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: That's my office.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Spoke like an officer: ha' to thee, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Head and butt! An hasty-witted body Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, that you shall not; since you have begun, Have at you for a bitter jest or two.

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush, And then pursue me as you draw your bow. You are welcome all.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio; This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not: Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: O, sir! Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound, Which runs himself, and catches for his master.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A good swift simile, but something currish.

dialogues.speaker: Tranio
dialogues.line: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Confess, confess; hath he not hit you here?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A has a little gall'd me, I confess; And as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Well, I say no; and therefore, for assurance, Let's each one send unto his wife, And he whose wife is most obedient, To come at first when he doth send for her, Shall win the wager which we will propose.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Content. What's the wager?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Twenty crowns.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Twenty crowns! I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: A hundred then.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Content.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: A match! 'tis done.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Who shall begin?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: That will I. Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: I go.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself. How now! what news?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy and she cannot come.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: How! She's busy, and she cannot come! Is that an answer?

dialogues.speaker: Gremio
dialogues.line: Ay, and a kind one too: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I hope better.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife To come to me forthwith.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: O, ho! entreat her! Nay, then she must needs come.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I am afraid, sir, Do what you can, yours will not be entreated. Now, where's my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Biondello
dialogues.line: She says you have some goodly jest in hand: She will not come; she bids you come to her.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile, Intolerable, not to be endur'd! Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress, Say I command her come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: I know her answer.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: She will not.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katherina!

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: What is your will sir, that you send for me?

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: They sit conferring by the parlour fire.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Go fetch them hither; if they deny to come, Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands. Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: And so it is. I wonder what it bodes.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life, An awful rule, and right supremacy; And, to be short, what not that's sweet and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Baptista
dialogues.line: Now fair befall thee, good Petruchio! The wager thou hast won; and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns; Another dowry to another daughter, For she is chang'd, as she had never been.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Nay, I will win my wager better yet, And show more sign of her obedience, Her new-built virtue and obedience. See where she comes, and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion. Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not: Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: I would your duty were as foolish too; The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me a hundred crowns since supper-time!

dialogues.speaker: Bianca
dialogues.line: The more fool you for laying on my duty.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Katherine, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Come, come, you're mocking; we will have no telling.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: She shall not.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

dialogues.speaker: Katherina
dialogues.line: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow, And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor: It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads, Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds, And in no sense is meet or amiable. A woman mov'd is like a fountain troubled, Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty; And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it. Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper, Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee, And for thy maintenance commits his body To painful labour both by sea and land, To watch the night in storms, the day in cold, Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe; And craves no other tribute at thy hands But love, fair looks, and true obedience; Too little payment for so great a debt. Such duty as the subject owes the prince, Even such a woman oweth to her husband; And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?- I am asham'd that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace, Or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway, When they are bound to serve, love, and obey. Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts? Come, come, you froward and unable worms! My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown; But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are. Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot, And place your hands below your husband's foot: In token of which duty, if he please, My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha't.

dialogues.speaker: Vincentio
dialogues.line: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

dialogues.speaker: Petruchio
dialogues.line: Come, Kate, we'll to bed. We three are married, but you two are sped. 'Twas I won the wager,  though you hit the white; And being a winner, God give you good night!

dialogues.speaker: Hortensio
dialogues.line: Now go thy ways; thou hast tam'd a curst shrew.

dialogues.speaker: Lucentio
dialogues.line: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tam'd so.
